subject: Re: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... I never reach for the debugger. I don t know how to use it. I try and make the tests as self-explanatory as possible. And run them as often as reasonably
messageBody:
On Wednesday 17 September 2003 17:39, Malcolm Sparks wrote:
>
> I'm interested in this stuff because I'm interested in the process
> different programmers choose to adopt when using JUnit. For example,
> when you write a failing test you can often get it to pass once you
> implement the functionality. Sometimes, however, the test still fails
> unexpectedly. That's why tests are so useful, they tell you you've made
> a mistake immediately. Programmers who don't write tests would assume
> at the point of implementation that they hadn't made a mistake and
> continue with the next task.
>
> How do people fix such a failing test? What information do you use to
> diagnose and fix it? Or is it always the time to reach for your
> debugger?

I never reach for the debugger. I don't know how to use it.

I try and make the tests as self-explanatory as possible. And run them as
often as reasonably possible, so that I know what changes are responsible
for the sudden failure.

And when I have no clue, I drop println()s in appropriate places to try and
get one, fix the problem, remove the printlns, and see if there's a way
I can expose the same information with a test. But JBR is right: printlns
(and logs) in tests are tempting but dangerous. Better would be

assertTrue( informative message, boolean )

It is a deep shame that Java doesn't have method literals (aka lambdas,
or Smalltalk blocks, or whatever) so that `informative message` could be
a hairy expression that's not actually evaluated unless the test fails.

--
Chris "#define ... #define ... NO! DON'T TEMPT ME!" Dollin
